About Me

I am a freelance Full Stack Web Developer who designs and programs reliable, maintainable web sites. I'm enthusiastic about accessibility, simplicity, and clean code.

Skills: Semantic HTML, CSS (SCSS & BEM), Javascript, Git Version Control (Github), Web Design (Adobe XD), and Web Accessibility.

 

Portfolio

View Project

Reels

Reels was a collaborative application that utilizes a movie database (themoviedb.org) to return all movies of a chosen genre within a chosen year, which the user can then flip through (the concept was to mimmic "swiping" like on dating apps). My role on this project was front-end engineer, and I worked with a second front-end engineer and a back-end engineer.

View Project

Moose Club

Moose Club is a simple responsive landing page containing a text overview of the purpose of the website or organization, with a photo gallery. The site accessible and responsive for all screen sizes. (Moose is my dog).

View Project

RNM!

Random Number Melee is an interactive guessing game with a simple yet creative design.

 

CV

Web Development Portfolio Projects (2021)

My focus throughout the Codecademy learning path has been to get my hands dirty with real practical projects, in both independent and team settings. These are the projects listed above in the Portfolio section.

Codecademy Full Stack Career Path (2021)

Codecademy is a leader of self-paced online education for tech. Their lessons and exercises have been useful to gain fundamental understanding of all the topics and skills needed for web development, and I frequently expand on topics learned through independent study and projects. I began this course in February 2021, and am currently 33% through it. I have completed most of the front-end work, with mostly back-end and framework material to go.

Geologist at Chevron (2018-2020)

At chevron I practiced working in complex multi-disciplinary teams on highly technical projects. I gained project management skills, and learned first hand the delicate balance between deadlines and "perfect" technical work. Although my geologic technical skills are not directly related to programming, geology is all about solving complex spatial and temporal problems which I believe have analogous applications in web development.

M.S. in Geology, University of Utah (2018)

My research incorporated spatial statistics with traditional geologic field work to quantify the geometry of sandstone bodies in southern Utah. I collected 4.5 km of drone imagery and GPS data, with which I developed a 3D photorealistic model of the outcrop. I then interpreted channel belts on the model and transformed them using ArcGIS into a dataset of points and polygons to perform statistical analyses on in MATLAB. This was my introduction to both coding and advanced statistical techniques. Without formal education on these skills, I was able to overcome many challenges and produce code that did complex statistical analyses on my dataset. I used both spatial point pattern analyses and more traditional analyses (average thickness of sand bodies, area of sand bodies, etc.) across various sizes of moving windows to allow greater prediction from 1D to 2D and 3D. My results can be used as an analog by those working in the subsurface to improve their predictions.

B.S. in Geology, UNC Wilmington (2015)

Undergraduate Research: Sandstone petrofacies and detrital zircon geochronology of the Permian–Early Jurassic Baker terrane mélange belt, northeastern Oregon. Presented as a poster at the Southeastern GSA Section Meeting, 2015. Advisor: Dr. Todd LaMaskin, Co-author: Dr. Josh Schwartz. Through this research I received ample practice using the petrographic microscope, particularly for sandstone petrography. I developed basic lab skills such as cutting rocks for thin section production, and using the jawcrusher to prepare mudrocks for geochemical analysis. I practiced basic skills in Chemistry, Physics, and Calculus.
